t: Hosea 1
The*p word of the Lord*s that came to Hosea son of Beeri during the reigns of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz and Hezekiah, kings of Judah, and during the reign of Jeroboam son of Jehoash king of Israel:
Hosea’s Wife and Children

When*p the Lord*s began to speak through Hosea, the Lord*s said to him, “Go, marry a promiscuous woman and have children with her, for like an adulterous wife this land is guilty of unfaithfulness to the Lord.”*s
So he married Gomer daughter of Diblaim, and she conceived and bore him a son.
Then*p the Lord*s said to Hosea, “Call him Jezreel, because I will soon punish the house of Jehu for the massacre at Jezreel, and I will put an end to the kingdom of Israel.
In that day I will break Israel’s bow in the Valley of Jezreel.”

Gomer*p conceived again and gave birth to a daughter. Then the Lord*s said to Hosea, “Call her Lo-Ruhamah (which means “not loved”), for I will no longer show love to Israel, that I should at all forgive them.
Yet I will show love to Judah; and I will save them—not by bow, sword or battle, or by horses and horsemen, but I, the Lord*s their God, will save them.”
After*p she had weaned Lo-Ruhamah, Gomer had another son.
Then the Lord*s said, “Call him Lo-Ammi (which means “not my people”), for you are not my people, and I am not your God.

“Yet*p the Israelites will be like the sand on the seashore, which cannot be measured or counted. In the place where it was said to them, ‘You are not my people,’ they will be called ‘children of the living God.’
The people of Judah and the people of Israel will come together; they will appoint one leader and will come up out of the land, for great will be the day of Jezreel.
Hosea 2
“Say*p of your brothers, ‘My people,’ and of your sisters, ‘My loved one.’
Israel Punished and Restored
“Rebuke*pn your mother, rebuke her, for*ld she is not my wife, and*ld I am not her husband. Let*ln her remove the adulterous look from her face and*ld the unfaithfulness from between her breasts.
Otherwise*ln I will strip her naked and*ld make her as bare as on the day she was born; I*ln will make her like a desert, turn*ld her into a parched land, and*ld slay her with thirst.
I*ln will not show my love to her children, because*ld they are the children of adultery.

Their*ln mother has been unfaithful and*ld has conceived them in disgrace. She*ln said, ‘I will go after my lovers, who*ld give me my food and my water, my*ld wool and my linen, my olive oil and my drink.’
Therefore*ln I will block her path with thornbushes; I*ld will wall her in so that she cannot find her way.

She*ln will chase after her lovers but not catch them; she*ld will look for them but not find them. Then*ln she will say, ‘I*ld will go back to my husband as at first, for*ld then I was better off than now.’
She*ln has not acknowledged that I was the one who*ld gave her the grain, the new wine and oil, who*ln lavished on her the silver and gold— which*ld they used for Baal.
“Therefore*pn I will take away my grain when it ripens, and*ld my new wine when it is ready. I*ln will take back my wool and my linen, intended*ld to cover her naked body.
So*ln now I will expose her lewdness before*ld the eyes of her lovers; no*ld one will take her out of my hands.
I*ln will stop all her celebrations: her*ld yearly festivals, her New Moons, her*ld Sabbath days—all her appointed festivals.
I*ln will ruin her vines and her fig trees, which*ld she said were her pay from her lovers; I*ln will make them a thicket, and*ld wild animals will devour them.
I*ln will punish her for the days she*ld burned incense to the Baals; she*ln decked herself with rings and jewelry, and*ld went after her lovers, but*ld me she forgot,” declares*ld the Lord.*s
“Therefore*pn I am now going to allure her; I*ld will lead her into the wilderness and*ld speak tenderly to her.
There*ln I will give her back her vineyards, and*ld will make the Valley of Achor a door of hope. There*ln she will respond as in the days of her youth, as*ld in the day she came up out of Egypt.
“In*pn that day,” declares the Lord,*s “you*ld will call me ‘my husband’; you*ld will no longer call me ‘my master.’
I*ln will remove the names of the Baals from her lips; no*ld longer will their names be invoked.

In*ln that day I will make a covenant for them with*ld the beasts of the field, the birds in the sky and*ld the creatures that move along the ground. Bow*ln and sword and battle I*ld will abolish from the land, so*ld that all may lie down in safety.
I*ln will betroth you to me forever; I*ld will betroth you in righteousness and justice, in*ld love and compassion.
I*ln will betroth you in faithfulness, and*ld you will acknowledge the Lord.*s
“In*pn that day I will respond,” declares*ld the Lord—*s “I*ln will respond to the skies, and*ld they will respond to the earth;
and*ln the earth will respond to the grain, the*ld new wine and the olive oil, and*ld they will respond to Jezreel.

I*ln will plant her for myself in the land; I*ld will show my love to the one I called ‘Not my loved one.’ I*ln will say to those called ‘Not my people,’ ‘You are my people’; and*ld they will say, ‘You are my God.’ ”
Hosea 3
Hosea’s Reconciliation With His Wife

The*p Lord*s said to me, “Go, show your love to your wife again, though she is loved by another man and is an adulteress. Love her as the Lord*s loves the Israelites, though they turn to other gods and love the sacred raisin cakes.”
So*p I bought her for fifteen shekels of silver and about a homer and a lethek of barley.
Then I told her, “You are to live with me many days; you must not be a prostitute or be intimate with any man, and I will behave the same way toward you.”
For*p the Israelites will live many days without king or prince, without sacrifice or sacred stones, without ephod or household gods.
Afterward the Israelites will return and seek the Lord*s their God and David their king. They will come trembling to the Lord*s and to his blessings in the last days.
Hosea 4
The Charge Against Israel

Hear*pn the word of the Lord,*s you Israelites, because*ld the Lord*s has a charge to bring against*ld you who live in the land: “There*ln is no faithfulness, no love, no*ld acknowledgment of God in the land.
There*ln is only cursing, lying and murder, stealing*ld and adultery; they*ln break all bounds, and*ld bloodshed follows bloodshed.
Because*ln of this the land dries up, and*ld all who live in it waste away; the*ln beasts of the field, the birds in the sky and*ld the fish in the sea are swept away.
“But*pn let no one bring a charge, let*ld no one accuse another, for*ln your people are like those who*ld bring charges against a priest.
You*ln stumble day and night, and*ld the prophets stumble with you. So*ln I will destroy your mother—

my*ld people are destroyed from lack of knowledge. “Because*pn you have rejected knowledge, I*ld also reject you as my priests; because*ln you have ignored the law of your God, I*ld also will ignore your children.
The*ln more priests there were, the*ld more they sinned against me; they*ld exchanged their glorious God for something disgraceful.
They*ln feed on the sins of my people and*ld relish their wickedness.
And*ln it will be: Like people, like priests. I*ld will punish both of them for their ways and*ld repay them for their deeds.
“They*pn will eat but not have enough; they*ld will engage in prostitution but not flourish, because*ln they have deserted the Lord*s to*ld give themselves
to prostitution; old*ln wine and new wine take*ld away their understanding.
My*ln people consult a wooden idol, and*ld a diviner’s rod speaks to them. A*ln spirit of prostitution leads them astray; they*ld are unfaithful to their God.

They*ln sacrifice on the mountaintops and*ld burn offerings on the hills, under*ln oak, poplar and terebinth, where*ld the shade is pleasant. Therefore*ln your daughters turn to prostitution and*ld your daughters-in-law to adultery.

“I*pn will not punish your daughters when*ld they turn to prostitution, nor*ln your daughters-in-law when*ld they commit adultery, because*ln the men themselves consort with harlots and*ld sacrifice with shrine prostitutes— a*ld people without understanding will come to ruin!
“Though*pn you, Israel, commit adultery, do*ld not let Judah become guilty. “Do*pn not go to Gilgal; do*ld not go up to Beth Aven. And*ld do not swear, ‘As surely as the Lord*s lives!’
The*ln Israelites are stubborn, like*ld a stubborn heifer. How*ln then can the Lord*s pasture them like*ld lambs in a meadow?
Ephraim*ln is joined to idols; leave*ld him alone!
Even*ln when their drinks are gone, they*ld continue their prostitution; their*ld rulers dearly love shameful ways.
A*ln whirlwind will sweep them away, and*ld their sacrifices will bring them shame.
Hosea 5
Judgment Against Israel
“Hear*pn this, you priests! Pay*ld attention, you Israelites! Listen,*ln royal house! This*ld judgment is against you: You*ln have been a snare at Mizpah, a*ld net spread out on Tabor.
The*ln rebels are knee-deep in slaughter. I*ld will discipline all of them.
I*ln know all about Ephraim; Israel*ld is not hidden from me. Ephraim,*ln you have now turned to prostitution; Israel*ld is corrupt.
“Their*pn deeds do not permit them to*ld return to their God. A*ln spirit of prostitution is in their heart; they*ld do not acknowledge the Lord.*s
Israel’s*ln arrogance testifies against them; the*ld Israelites, even Ephraim, stumble in their sin; Judah*ld also stumbles with them.
When*ln they go with their flocks and herds to*ld seek the Lord,*s they*ln will not find him; he*ld has withdrawn himself from them.
They*ln are unfaithful to the Lord;*s they*ld give birth to illegitimate children. When*ln they celebrate their New Moon feasts, he*ld will devour their fields.
“Sound*pn the trumpet in Gibeah, the*ld horn in Ramah. Raise*ln the battle cry in Beth Aven; lead*ld on, Benjamin.
Ephraim*ln will be laid waste on*ld the day of reckoning. Among*ln the tribes of Israel I*ld proclaim what is certain.
Judah’s*ln leaders are like those who*ld move boundary stones. I*ln will pour out my wrath on them like*ld a flood of water.
Ephraim*ln is oppressed, trampled*ld in judgment, intent*ld on pursuing idols.
I*ln am like a moth to Ephraim, like*ld rot to the people of Judah.

“When*pn Ephraim saw his sickness, and*ld Judah his sores, then*ln Ephraim turned to Assyria, and*ld sent to the great king for help. But*ln he is not able to cure you, not*ld able to heal your sores.
For*ln I will be like a lion to Ephraim, like*ld a great lion to Judah. I*ln will tear them to pieces and go away; I*ld will carry them off, with no one to rescue them.
Then*ln I will return to my lair until*ld they have borne their guilt and*ld seek my face— in*ln their misery they*ld will earnestly seek me.”
Hosea 6
Israel Unrepentant
“Come,*pn let us return to the Lord.*s He*ln has torn us to pieces but*ld he will heal us; he*ln has injured us but*ld he will bind up our wounds.
After*ln two days he will revive us; on*ld the third day he will restore us, that*ld we may live in his presence.

Let*ln us acknowledge the Lord;*s let*ld us press on to acknowledge him. As*ln surely as the sun rises, he*ld will appear; he*ln will come to us like the winter rains, like*ld the spring rains that water the earth.”
“What*pn can I do with you, Ephraim? What*ld can I do with you, Judah? Your*ln love is like the morning mist, like*ld the early dew that disappears.
Therefore*ln I cut you in pieces with my prophets, I*ld killed you with the words of my mouth— then*ld my judgments go forth like the sun.
For*ln I desire mercy, not sacrifice, and*ld acknowledgment of God rather than burnt offerings.
As*ln at Adam, they have broken the covenant; they*ld were unfaithful to me there.
Gilead*ln is a city of evildoers, stained*ld with footprints of blood.
As*ln marauders lie in ambush for a victim, so*ld do bands of priests; they*ln murder on the road to Shechem, carrying*ld out their wicked schemes.
I*ln have seen a horrible thing in Israel: There*ld Ephraim is given to prostitution, Israel*ld is defiled.
“Also*pn for you, Judah, a*ld harvest is appointed. “Whenever*pn I would restore the fortunes of my people,
Hosea 7
whenever*ld I would heal Israel, the*ln sins of Ephraim are exposed and*ld the crimes of Samaria revealed. They*ln practice deceit, thieves*ld break into houses, bandits*ld rob in the streets;
but*ln they do not realize that*ld I remember all their evil deeds. Their*ln sins engulf them; they*ld are always before me.
“They*pn delight the king with their wickedness, the*ld princes with their lies.
They*ln are all adulterers, burning*ld like an oven whose*ln fire the baker need not stir from*ld the kneading of the dough till it rises.
On*ln the day of the festival of our king the*ld princes become inflamed with wine, and*ld he joins hands with the mockers.
Their*ln hearts are like an oven; they*ld approach him with intrigue. Their*ln passion smolders all night; in*ld the morning it blazes like a flaming fire.
All*ln of them are hot as an oven; they*ld devour their rulers. All*ln their kings fall, and*ld none of them calls on me.
“Ephraim*pn mixes with the nations; Ephraim*ld is a flat loaf not turned over.
Foreigners*ln sap his strength, but*ld he does not realize it. His*ln hair is sprinkled with gray, but*ld he does not notice.
Israel’s*ln arrogance testifies against him, but*ld despite all this he*ln does not return to the Lord*s his God or*ld search for him.
“Ephraim*pn is like a dove, easily*ld deceived and senseless— now*ln calling to Egypt, now*ld turning to Assyria.
When*ln they go, I will throw my net over them; I*ld will pull them down like the birds in the sky. When*ln I hear them flocking together, I*ld will catch them.
Woe*ln to them, because*ld they have strayed from me! Destruction*ln to them, because*ld they have rebelled against me! I*ln long to redeem them but*ld they speak about me falsely.
They*ln do not cry out to me from their hearts but*ld wail on their beds. They*ln slash themselves, appealing to their gods for*ld grain and new wine, but*ld they turn away from me.
I*ln trained them and strengthened their arms, but*ld they plot evil against me.

They*ln do not turn to the Most High; they*ld are like a faulty bow. Their*ln leaders will fall by the sword because*ld of their insolent words. For*ln this they will be ridiculed in*ld the land of Egypt.
Hosea 8
Israel to Reap the Whirlwind
“Put*pn the trumpet to your lips! An*ld eagle is over the house of the Lord*s because*ln the people have broken my covenant and*ld rebelled against my law.
Israel*ln cries out to me, ‘Our*ld God, we acknowledge you!’
But*ln Israel has rejected what is good; an*ld enemy will pursue him.
They*ln set up kings without my consent; they*ld choose princes without my approval. With*ln their silver and gold they*ld make idols for themselves to*ld their own destruction.
Samaria,*ln throw out your calf-idol! My*ld anger burns against them. How*ln long will they be incapable of purity?
They*ld are from Israel! This*ln calf—a metalworker has made it; it*ld is not God. It*ln will be broken in pieces, that*ld calf of Samaria.
“They*pn sow the wind and*ld reap the whirlwind. The*ln stalk has no head; it*ld will produce no flour. Were*ln it to yield grain, foreigners*ld would swallow it up.
Israel*ln is swallowed up; now*ld she is among the nations like*ld something no one wants.
For*ln they have gone up to Assyria like*ld a wild donkey wandering alone. Ephraim*ld has sold herself to lovers.
Although*ln they have sold themselves among the nations, I*ld will now gather them together. They*ln will begin to waste away under*ld the oppression of the mighty king.
“Though*pn Ephraim built many altars for sin offerings, these*ld have become altars for sinning.
I*ln wrote for them the many things of my law, but*ld they regarded them as something foreign.

Though*ln they offer sacrifices as gifts to me, and*ld though they eat the meat, the*ld Lord*s is not pleased with them. Now*ln he will remember their wickedness and*ld punish their sins: They*ld will return to Egypt.
Israel*ln has forgotten their Maker and*ld built palaces; Judah*ld has fortified many towns. But*ln I will send fire on their cities that*ld will consume their fortresses.”
Hosea 9
Punishment for Israel
Do*pn not rejoice, Israel; do*ld not be jubilant like the other nations. For*ln you have been unfaithful to your God; you*ld love the wages of a prostitute at*ld every threshing floor.
Threshing*ln floors and winepresses will not feed the people; the*ld new wine will fail them.
They*ln will not remain in the Lord’s*s land; Ephraim*ld will return to Egypt and*ld eat unclean food in Assyria.

They*ln will not pour out wine offerings to the Lord,*s nor*ld will their sacrifices please him. Such*ln sacrifices will be to them like the bread of mourners; all*ld who eat them will be unclean. This*ln food will be for themselves; it*ld will not come into the temple of the Lord.*s
What*pn will you do on the day of your appointed festivals, on*ld the feast days of the Lord?*s
Even*ln if they escape from destruction, Egypt*ld will gather them, and*ld Memphis will bury them. Their*ln treasures of silver will be taken over by briers, and*ld thorns will overrun their tents.

The*ln days of punishment are coming, the*ld days of reckoning are at hand. Let*ld Israel know this. Because*ln your sins are so many and*ld your hostility so great, the*ln prophet is considered a fool, the*ld inspired person a maniac.
The*ln prophet, along with my God, is*ld the watchman over Ephraim, yet*ln snares await him on all his paths, and*ld hostility in the house of his God.
They*ln have sunk deep into corruption, as*ld in the days of Gibeah. God*ln will remember their wickedness and*ld punish them for their sins.

“When*pn I found Israel, it*ld was like finding grapes in the desert; when*ln I saw your ancestors, it*ld was like seeing the early fruit on the fig tree. But*ln when they came to Baal Peor, they*ld consecrated themselves to that shameful idol and*ld became as vile as the thing they loved.
Ephraim’s*ln glory will fly away like a bird— no*ld birth, no pregnancy, no conception.
Even*ln if they rear children, I*ld will bereave them of every one. Woe*ln to them when*ld I turn away from them!
I*ln have seen Ephraim, like Tyre, planted*ld in a pleasant place. But*ln Ephraim will bring out their*ld children to the slayer.”
Give*pn them, Lord—*s what*ld will you give them? Give*ln them wombs that miscarry and*ld breasts that are dry.

“Because*pn of all their wickedness in Gilgal, I*ld hated them there. Because*ln of their sinful deeds, I*ld will drive them out of my house. I*ln will no longer love them; all*ld their leaders are rebellious.
Ephraim*ln is blighted, their*ld root is withered, they*ld yield no fruit. Even*ln if they bear children, I*ld will slay their cherished offspring.”
My*pn God will reject them because*ld they have not obeyed him; they*ld will be wanderers among the nations.
Hosea 10
Israel*pn was a spreading vine; he*ld brought forth fruit for himself. As*ln his fruit increased, he*ld built more altars; as*ln his land prospered, he*ld adorned his sacred stones.
Their*ln heart is deceitful, and*ld now they must bear their guilt. The*ln Lord*s will demolish their altars and*ld destroy their sacred stones.
Then*pn they will say, “We have no king because*ld we did not revere the Lord.*s But*ln even if we had a king, what*ld could he do for us?”
They*ln make many promises, take*ld false oaths and*ld make agreements; therefore*ln lawsuits spring up like*ld poisonous weeds in a plowed field.

The*ln people who live in Samaria fear for*ld the calf-idol of Beth Aven. Its*ln people will mourn over it, and*ld so will its idolatrous priests, those*ln who had rejoiced over its splendor, because*ld it is taken from them into exile.
It*ln will be carried to Assyria as*ld tribute for the great king. Ephraim*ln will be disgraced; Israel*ld will be ashamed of its foreign alliances.
Samaria’s*ln king will be destroyed, swept*ld away like a twig on the surface of the waters.

The*ln high places of wickedness will be destroyed— it*ld is the sin of Israel. Thorns*ln and thistles will grow up and*ld cover their altars. Then*ln they will say to the mountains, “Cover us!” and*ld to the hills, “Fall on us!”
“Since*pn the days of Gibeah, you have sinned, Israel, and*ld there you have remained. Will*ln not war again overtake the*ld evildoers in Gibeah?
When*ln I please, I will punish them; nations*ld will be gathered against them to*ld put them in bonds for their double sin.
Ephraim*ln is a trained heifer that*ld loves to thresh; so*ln I will put a yoke on*ld her fair neck. I*ln will drive Ephraim, Judah*ld must plow, and*ld Jacob must break up the ground.

Sow*ln righteousness for yourselves, reap*ld the fruit of unfailing love, and*ln break up your unplowed ground; for*ld it is time to seek the Lord,*s until*ln he comes and*ld showers his righteousness on you.
But*ln you have planted wickedness, you*ld have reaped evil, you*ld have eaten the fruit of deception. Because*ln you have depended on your own strength and*ld on your many warriors,

the*ln roar of battle will rise against your people, so*ld that all your fortresses will be devastated— as*ln Shalman devastated Beth Arbel on the day of battle, when*ld mothers were dashed to the ground with their children.
So*ln will it happen to you, Bethel, because*ld your wickedness is great. When*ln that day dawns, the*ld king of Israel will be completely destroyed.
Hosea 11
God’s Love for Israel
“When*pn Israel was a child, I loved him, and*ld out of Egypt I called my son.
But*ln the more they were called, the*ld more they went away from me. They*ln sacrificed to the Baals and*ld they burned incense to images.
It*ln was I who taught Ephraim to walk, taking*ld them by the arms; but*ln they did not realize it*ld was I who healed them.
I*ln led them with cords of human kindness, with*ld ties of love. To*ln them I was like one who lifts a*ld little child to the cheek, and*ld I bent down to feed them.
“Will*pn they not return to Egypt and*ld will not Assyria rule over them because*ld they refuse to repent?
A*ln sword will flash in their cities; it*ld will devour their false prophets and*ld put an end to their plans.
My*ln people are determined to turn from me. Even*ld though they call me God Most High, I*ld will by no means exalt them.

“How*pn can I give you up, Ephraim? How*ld can I hand you over, Israel? How*ln can I treat you like Admah? How*ld can I make you like Zeboyim? My*ln heart is changed within me; all*ld my compassion is aroused.
I*ln will not carry out my fierce anger, nor*ld will I devastate Ephraim again. For*ln I am God, and not a man— the*ld Holy One among you. I*ld will not come against their cities.
They*ln will follow the Lord;*s he*ld will roar like a lion. When*ln he roars, his*ld children will come trembling from the west.
They*ln will come from Egypt, trembling*ld like sparrows, from*ld Assyria, fluttering like doves. I*ln will settle them in their homes,” declares*ld the Lord.*s
Israel’s Sin
Ephraim*pn has surrounded me with lies, Israel*ld with deceit. And*ln Judah is unruly against God, even*ld against the faithful Holy One.
Hosea 12
Ephraim*pn feeds on the wind; he*ld pursues the east wind all day and*ld multiplies lies and violence. He*ln makes a treaty with Assyria and*ld sends olive oil to Egypt.
The*ln Lord*s has a charge to bring against Judah; he*ld will punish Jacob according to his ways and*ld repay him according to his deeds.
In*ln the womb he grasped his brother’s heel; as*ld a man he struggled with God.
He*ln struggled with the angel and overcame him; he*ld wept and begged for his favor. He*ln found him at Bethel and*ld talked with him there—
the*ln Lord*s God Almighty, the*ld Lord*s is his name!
But*ln you must return to your God; maintain*ld love and justice, and*ld wait for your God always.
The*pn merchant uses dishonest scales and*ld loves to defraud.
Ephraim*ln boasts, “I*ld am very rich; I have become wealthy. With*ln all my wealth they will not find in me any*ld iniquity or sin.”
“I*pn have been the Lord*s your God ever*ld since you came out of Egypt; I*ln will make you live in tents again, as*ld in the days of your appointed festivals.
I*ln spoke to the prophets, gave*ld them many visions and*ld told parables through them.”
Is*pn Gilead wicked? Its*ld people are worthless! Do*ln they sacrifice bulls in Gilgal? Their*ld altars will be like piles of stones on*ld a plowed field.
Jacob*ln fled to the country of Aram; Israel*ld served to get a wife, and*ld to pay for her he tended sheep.
The*ln Lord*s used a prophet to bring Israel up from Egypt, by*ld a prophet he cared for him.
But*ln Ephraim has aroused his bitter anger; his*ld Lord will leave on him the guilt of his bloodshed and*ld will repay him for his contempt.
Hosea 13
The Lord’s Anger Against Israel
When*pn Ephraim spoke, people trembled; he*ld was exalted in Israel. But*ld he became guilty of Baal worship and died.

Now*ln they sin more and more; they*ld make idols for themselves from their silver, cleverly*ln fashioned images, all*ld of them the work of craftsmen. It*ln is said of these people, “They*ld offer human sacrifices! They*ld kiss calf-idols!”
Therefore*ln they will be like the morning mist, like*ld the early dew that disappears, like*ld chaff swirling from a threshing floor, like*ld smoke escaping through a window.
“But*pn I have been the Lord*s your God ever*ld since you came out of Egypt. You*ln shall acknowledge no God but me, no*ld Savior except me.
I*ln cared for you in the wilderness, in*ld the land of burning heat.
When*ln I fed them, they were satisfied; when*ld they were satisfied, they became proud; then*ld they forgot me.
So*ln I will be like a lion to them, like*ld a leopard I will lurk by the path.
Like*ln a bear robbed of her cubs, I*ld will attack them and rip them open; like*ln a lion I will devour them— a*ld wild animal will tear them apart.
“You*pn are destroyed, Israel, because*ld you are against me, against your helper.
Where*ln is your king, that he may save you? Where*ld are your rulers in all your towns, of*ln whom you said, ‘Give*ld me a king and princes’?
So*ln in my anger I gave you a king, and*ld in my wrath I took him away.
The*ln guilt of Ephraim is stored up, his*ld sins are kept on record.
Pains*ln as of a woman in childbirth come to him, but*ld he is a child without wisdom; when*ln the time arrives, he*ld doesn’t have the sense to come out of the womb.

“I*pn will deliver this people from the power of the grave; I*ld will redeem them from death. Where,*ln O death, are your plagues? Where,*ld O grave, is your destruction? “I*pn will have no compassion,

even*ld though he thrives among his brothers. An*ln east wind from the Lord*s will come, blowing*ld in from the desert; his*ln spring will fail and*ld his well dry up. His*ln storehouse will be plundered of*ld all its treasures.

The*ln people of Samaria must bear their guilt, because*ld they have rebelled against their God. They*ln will fall by the sword; their*ld little ones will be dashed to the ground, their*ld pregnant women ripped open.”
Hosea 14
Repentance to Bring Blessing
Return,*pn Israel, to the Lord*s your God. Your*ld sins have been your downfall!
Take*ln words with you and*ld return to the Lord.*s Say*ln to him: “Forgive*ld all our sins and*ln receive us graciously, that*ld we may offer the fruit of our lips.
Assyria*ln cannot save us; we*ld will not mount warhorses. We*ln will never again say ‘Our gods’ to*ld what our own hands have made, for*ld in you the fatherless find compassion.”
“I*pn will heal their waywardness and*ld love them freely, for*ld my anger has turned away from them.
I*ln will be like the dew to Israel; he*ld will blossom like a lily. Like*ln a cedar of Lebanon he*ld will send down his roots;
his*ld young shoots will grow. His*ln splendor will be like an olive tree, his*ld fragrance like a cedar of Lebanon.
